title: Universal Board Rules Update
body:
Hello,** Boards!**

It’s been a while since the [**Universal Rules**](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/community-moderation/ITFIpNUE) have been really looked at, and today we’re pushing out an update to them based on feedback we’ve received from the community. Here’s a quick rundown of the major changes, although we encourage *every* board member to review the rules and read the new additions:
---------------------
#MAJOR RULES CHANGES
We’ve added three new specific rules – while all of these rules were implied by previous rules, we’ve called them out specifically as these are things that we’ve heard pretty loudly players want to see less of (well, nobody was begging for a “No sharing personal information” rules, but it seemed important).


**Gameplay and Rank Shaming [Added]:** No belittling or shaming a player for their champion pool, rank, playstyle, or match history.


**Pejorative Language [Added]:**  Do not use language intended to express contempt for an individual on the basis of ethnicity/race, sexual orientation, political affiliation, gender, religion, etc. This includes, but is not limited to, examples such as “gay”, “retarded”, “autistic”, “cuck”, “jew”, etc., even if intended humorously or jokingly.

**Sharing Personal Information [Added]:** Do not post personal information belonging to yourself or another player. This includes, but is not limited to, the following: real names, addresses, e-mail addresses, phone numbers, Facebook profiles, etc. The sole exception is for streams/fan pages/names belonging to individuals who have opted to reveal this information to the public.


**The Good Stuff [Added]:** A section detailing some positive board behaviors that are great to aspire to. It’s worth reading, as if your post is adhering to these principles you’ve got nothing to worry about. If it looks a bit like the Summoner’s Code tweaked to apply to the boards, well…

-------------------
#ORGANIZATION CHANGES
You’ll see three sections (Good Stuff, Bad Stuff, and Really Bad Stuff) to help convey which behaviors we consider most problematic, some more links to the moderation discord and/or player support, some wording changes for clarity, and a nifty new drop-down format.

-----------------------------

#[You can find the updated Universal Rules here.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/community-moderation/ITFIpNUE)

> Do not post or engage in discussions of religion, ethnicity/race, sexual orientation, gender, politics, or real-world social issues.

Really? Are we encouraging censored platforms now as if we're living in North Korea?
I fully understand that these topics will usually lead to heated discussions, yet any possible violation of board rules is already listed under a different category. If a discussion is getting out of hand, there already is a reason to close it and/or ban offensive commenters due to violation of the already listed rules (e.g. "hate speech", or anything else that was violated).
*That being said, I see no reason to censor and prohibit these types of discussions solely based on their nature.* 
Doing so seems like nothing short of creating a dystopian platform to me.

> **Pejorative Language:** This includes, but is not limited to, examples such as “gay”, “retarded”, “autistic”, “cuck”, “jew”, etc., even if intended humorously or jokingly.

Will these words be banned only if used in a **pejorative manner**? I'm quite literally a jew and a bisexual person irl, and seeing two of my identities in a "these words are offensive" list once again leads me to believe something went horribly wrong down the line of the decision making here.

This rules has always existed, actually. It is simply more visible due to the new format.

The reason that rule is in effect is it's our experience, after several experiments where we allowed threads about those topics, that they almost unanimously spiral out of control and we are forced to take action, often against individuals whose behavior is otherwise perfectly fine, but who get pulled into these volatile topics.

Every now and then we take a look at this rule to see whether it needs to remain, and if we see a notable increase in how frequently these threads are handled appropriately when they are allowed, we may consider adjusting this rule.

> Will these words be banned only if used in a **pejorative manner**? I'm quite literally a jew and a bisexual person irl, and seeing two of my identities in a "these words are offensive" list once again leads me to believe something went horribly wrong down the line of the decision making here.

Saying "I'm Jewish and I'm bisexual" or "my gay friend loved the rainbow poro icon" is fine. Saying "typical bi jew" in response to someone's opinion wouldn't be.

So yes, there is some discretionary space if you're using words non-insultingly. The reason we pushed this rule out, however, is that we saw a lot of instances of these terms used insultingly and wanted to clarify that thay isn't okay.

These threads are always discretionary, depending on the tone and content. Historically we have given leeway to threads that are especially relevant to the boards community, such as Net Neutrality or minority representation in League, but I would recommend visiting the moderation discord before making a thread you feel crosses those lines, so we can help advise on how (or if) it can be made board appropriate.

Because yes -- we do want people to be able to discuss things like the harassment of streamers, or the presentation of minorities in *League*, but we have to be careful these topics are being discussed properly, and not as proxies for other issues or as places to vent political/social anger.

That makes sense. I guess my worry is that people with the agenda of preventing these discussions could aggressively make bad-faith threads or posts on existing threads with the goal of getting the topic banned (or getting controversial but good-faith threads closed by exploding on them). There's a relatively small, but incredibly vocal faction of gamers as a whole that are super invested in not allowing these conversations to happen, and I would hope you have a clear policy/plan for protecting these discussions from them.

> [{quoted}](name=iraklissid,realm=EUNE,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=0012,timestamp=2018-06-14T13:01:32.307+0000)but do we forget that the first black champion riot released lucian{{champion:236}}  was holding two guns or we forget that the second black champ reffering to ekko {{champion:245}}  [ some of you may not agree with this based on how he looks in the splash art ] stole a time machine in his lore? isnt that racism and usage of stereotypes.

Anyone who actively looks for reasons to be offended will find them, yes.

Lucian is a heroic and moral character. He just happens to fight with guns, which has nothing to do with his race and everything to do with his character fantasy. The "heroic anti-supernatural gunslinger" is a trope from many forms of media, and simply because Lucian is a BLACK anti-supernatural gunslinger doesn't make that racist. Sure, you could MAKE it racist if you leaned into certain stereotypes, but Lucian's character portrayal definitely avoids that.

Ekko didn't really steal anything -- he took a crystal from the rubble of a demolished lab, and invented his own device around it. He's an ingenous child turned mage-punk hero, and the fact that he happens to be black doesn't make him a stereotype.

In effect, people need to realize that a character's skin color is just that -- a skin color. Unless we see enough stereotypical elements to be insulting, it's safe to assume that you're simply reading too far into things. If criminals, gunslingers, mages, and great warriors exist in *League of Legends*, than a person of ANY skin color or ethnicity can be a criminal, gunslinger, mage, or great warrior.

----------------------------------

This is also entirely different from the use of pejorative language. "This gunslinging character happens to be black" is a description of a character that is neither inherently racist nor insulting. "You're a retarded cuck" is an insult, plain and simple.

> [{quoted}](name=LightTrack,realm=EUW,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=000b,timestamp=2018-06-12T18:39:20.683+0000)Why? If the parties involved understand they're both just fooling around and not attacking each other, this part seems pointless.

Because that quote is pulled from the pejorative language section. I frankly don't care if you and your friends use "that's gay" or "that's retarded" to mean different things when talking privately to each other, or if you find them light-hearted phrases. That's fine.

What's NOT fine is assuming you can use those usually-offensive words outside of that setting -- in front of the entire board community -- and assume that everyone will simply assume you meant them in a light-hearted or joking way.

In short, your friend may know that when you say "that's retarded" to him you *mean* "that's silly and unbelievable." No one on the boards knows that, and that word is typically used as an insult, and as a derogatory one at that. As such, it is not something we will be allowing.

> [{quoted}](name=Quinzley,realm=EUNE,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=000c0000000000000001,timestamp=2018-06-13T16:04:19.045+0000)But some people identify as cats. What now? Aren't cat jokes offensive to them and are aimed at their gender/sexuality?

If you are using the joke specifically to target their gender/sexuality, they yes. The simple fact is that it's typically assumed that "I fucking hate cats" isn't disparaging someone for their gender/sexuality, and "I fucking hate gays" *is* intended as that.

In effect, the answer to "where does it stop" is "somewhere."

> I hate the thought of a person's ideas being modified or even hushed because someone somewhere might not like to hear them. Outside actually breaking the law or causing someone physical harm "hurting someone's feelings" is almost impossible to objectively quantify.

"Hurting someone's feelings" also isn't on the list of things that aren't okay, because we understand that people can have hurt feelings about things that are frankly harmless to 99.99% of people and aren't intended to disparage or antagonize any specific group. We aren't going to do things like remove "I don't like cats" because someone who DOES like cats is offended. We ARE going to remove "I don't like jews" because that's clearly a social/racial/religious/ethnic/sexuality/condition related comment. Part of this is that the second is OBVIOUSLY designed to target someone, and the former could ACCIDENTALLY do that in HIGHLY SPECIFIC SITUATIONS.

If you are ever in doubt if a comment you wish to make is acceptable, you can always come to the Moderation Discord. We'll be happy to help you determine if it is acceptable or not.

> [{quoted}](name=kriegnes,realm=EUW,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=000c000000000000000100000001,timestamp=2018-06-22T15:34:38.839+0000)banning racism is ok but now you cant even make a joke? 

We're not banning humor. We're banning *specific types of comments* (humorous or not) that are not acceptable for use on the boards, and are consistent with behaviors that are not considered acceptable in the game.

"That's gay" isn't a joke -- it's the equivalent to calling something stupid, save that you're using "gay" to MEAN stupid, and in doing so insulting everyone who is gay by equating it with stupidity. When the punchline is "being gay is the same as being stupid," it's not a joke -- it's just derogatory.

I'm not saying that someone (gay or straight or otherwise) can't find it fucking hilarious -- I'm saying that the boards simply aren't the place for that. You and that individual are welcome to go somewhere else to yuck it up all you want, with my blessings.

I do have a question in regards to rank shaming, though it is 100% a rule that I understand. What if in the context, it's almost necessary to point out rank? For example: Player 1 is Bronze III claims Garen is OP and destroys every game he's in. Player 2 points out "Garen is fine. He probably does very well in your games because of the low elo you play in." or something along these lines. Is this permissible or is it still considered rank shaming?

I just imagine this rule was made to stop people from spouting things like "lol a silver 2 discussing balance" which i totally agree is a problem and should be addressed, but I'd just like some clarification if there are exceptions like the former example.

Commenting something in regards of rank, implying that there are differences in ranks should not be phrased by pointing out low skill of said rank but rather in a way that implies something being more common there. 
---

#Bad: 

>"Champion XY is not toxic because you are in low elo and nobody in low elo can play them properly".

[](http://1)

>"Champion XY is stomping in your games because players in low elo can't play against it".

---

#Good:

>"Champion XY is has a high skill ceiling so you don't see them as often played to their full potential in low elo".

[](http://1)

>"Champion XY is tends to be hard to deal with in low elo since he requires better organized teamplay as counterplay".

Well said. Pointing out trends in a skill range is fine, being insulting about them is not. If you're a platinum player, we all know you're likely better at pretty much everything about the game then someone in bronze 5. That still doesn't mean you have to call bronze 5 players bad, or call them noobs, or trash their opinions disrespectfully.
Sounds like it's doubleplusungood to use the skill measurement system Riot created to discuss skill.

> [{quoted}](name=sKz Aaron D,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=000300010001,timestamp=2018-06-14T03:05:23.654+0000)Sounds like it's doubleplusungood to use the skill measurement system Riot created to discuss skill.

Discussing skill is fine. Belittling someone else for their rank is not, nor is dismissing their comments simply due to their rank, or making fun of their lack of gameplay success. Hence the use of the word "shaming" rather than "mentioning." If mentioning someone's rank is important to the conversation and you discuss it in a respectful manner, that's fine.

I second this question. 
Rank is originally meant simply to match you with players of similar rank, aka matchmaking. 
Seeing board mods ban the very act of stating one's rank, if not used in a pejorative manner, is nothing short of enforcing the idea that rank is only used to praise and/or shame someone for their rank.

> [{quoted}](name=Altiverse,realm=EUNE,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=Rr5Ulb1z,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2018-06-12T10:16:11.249+0000)

> Seeing board mods ban the very act of stating one's rank, if not used in a pejorative manner, is nothing short of enforcing the idea that rank is only used to praise and/or shame someone for their rank.

The rule specifically states "belittling or shaming." If it's appropriate to the discussion to mention someone's rank (such as "Master Yi does often feel overpowered in lower MMRs due to the teamwork required to shut him down, which requires more coordination than you [the OP] probably see frequently in Silver" that's fine -- it's a statement of fact, and isn't insulting (although I'll point out you could make the same point without bringing rank into it at all).

"You only think he's too strong 'cause your Silver", on the other hand, isn't okay.

If you are not the belittling or shaming the player, discussion of rank is fine.

"Garen tends to do really well in your ranked bracket, because a lot of players there don't know the proper counterplay to him. Here are some tips." -- This is great.

"Garen tends to do really well in your ranked bracket because it's the lowest one out there and that's where all the noobs are." -- This is not great.

"Garen's fine if you aren't bronze. Learn to play." -- This is *definitely* not great.
